title: Relates to regulation of unsolicited advertisements and sale, rental or exchange of personal information
summary: Regulates persons who advertise using unsolicited written communications or telephone conservations to protect personal privacy; requires disclosure of the source of the listing and notice of right not to receive unsolicited telephone calls; requires advertising entities to maintain an exclusion list and authorizes a cause of action to enjoin unwanted solicitation.

       AN ACT to amend the general business law, in relation to the  regulation
         of  unsolicited  advertisements  and  the  sale, rental or exchange of
         personal information

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1.  Legislative  findings  and declaration.   The legislature
    2  hereby finds and declares that the use  of  computers,  data  bases  and
    3  information sharing threaten the privacy of our citizens. Personal iden-
    4  tification information is compiled and transferred without the knowledge
    5  and consent of the data subject.  In many situations, personal identifi-
    6  cation  information  is  being  used  for  secondary  purposes, purposes
    7  different from the one for which the information was originally given or
    8  obtained.  Improper collection and dissemination of personal identifica-
    9  tion information not only infringes upon individual privacy but also has
   10  increased the ability of unethical persons to engage in fraud and theft.
   11  In addition, collection and  dissemination  of  personal  identification
   12  information  can  threaten  the security of those who wish to keep their
   13  addresses and other information secret. For these reasons, the  legisla-
   14  ture  proposes  this  statute  to  provide a means by which citizens can
   15  protect their personal identification information.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1958

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the general business law, in relation to the regulation of
unsolicited advertisements and the sale, rental or exchange of
personal information

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
To protect personal privacy in the wake of the increased demand for
the collection and dissemination of personal information. To reduce
the proliferation of unsolicited advertisements attributable to the
marketing of personal information without the knowledge and consent
of the data subject. The legislation provides a means by which the
privacy of a consumer can be safeguarded if the consumer chooses that
option.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
The bill provides that whenever a person, firm, partnership,
corporation or association purchases or acquires through trade a
listing of persons utilizes in any unsolicited advertisement or
unsolicited telephone advertisement, such entity shall establish an
opt-out system and disclose to the consumer that he/she has the right
to restrict unsolicited advertisements. The entity shall maintain an
exclusion list of advertisement. Disclosure is not required in
instances where such entity has an established business relationship
with the consumer.

Additionally, whenever any person, firm, partnership, corporation, or
association sells, rents, exchanges or releases or is preparing to
sell, rent, release or exchange customer personal information, the
entity must establish a system whereby a client or customer can
opt-out of the practice of having his/her personal information
commercially released. In addition to disclosing to consumers the
practice of commercially trading customer information and the opt-out
option prior to selling, renting or releasing personal identification
information, a clear and conspicuous written notice disclosing this
practice must be given to the consumer or data subject upon initial
contact and on at least an annual basis. Such conspicuous notice may
be inserted in a mailing or billing statement.
Those consumers who want to restrict the sale or release of their
listing or personal identification information shall be listed on an
exclusion list. The list shall be used only for compliance with the
requirements of this act and not for trade or commercial purposes.

Whenever the court determines that a violation involving disclosure
occurred, the Court shall impose a civil penalty not to exceed two
hundred fifty dollars. When the court determines that a violation
involving the exclusion list has occurred, the court shall impose a
civil penalty of not more than five hundred dollars. A second or

subsequent offense shall be punishable by a civil penalty not to
exceed one.

No person, firm, partnership, corporation or association shall be
deemed to have violated the provisions, if such entity shows by a
preponderance of the evidence that the violation was not intentional
and resulted from a bona fide error made notwithstanding the
maintenance of procedures adopted to avoid such error. Any person
injured by reason of any violation may bring an action to recover
actual damages or fifty dollars, whichever is greater.

The court may increase the award to an amount not to exceed three
times the actual damages up to one thousand dollars if the court
finds that the defendant willfully or knowingly violated the
provisions.

EFFECTS OF PRESENT LAW WHICH THIS BILL WOULD ALTER:
The general business law is amended by adding two new sections 394-f
and 394-g.

JUSTIFICATION:
Advancements in computer science, telecommunication, and data
collection are having revolutionary impacts on our lives. Individuals
are losing control over personal and sensitive information and
lifestyle data.
Privacy is being slowly eroded. Data about almost every aspect of our
lives are being collected, stored, and sold faster than you can say
computer. The new technologies, which came of age in the 1980's, not
only, facilitate increased demands for personal information but also
more intrusive data collection and information sharing. Now,
sophisticated computer-matching projects allow companies to cross
reference and correlate extensive and highly detailed databanks.

Computer matching or databanking compares information on a database
with that on another often resulting in more detailed databases. By
overlaying the data available through many systems, it's now possible
to create a remarkably detailed picture of anyone. Rarely do they ask
our permission to use that information or sell it to others. We are
not compensated in any way and we are not given any opportunity to
ensure that the data are accurate. Data about almost every aspect of
our lives are being collected, stored and sold. Today, credit
bureaus, credit card companies, banks, publishers, telemarketers,
utilities, non-profits and other businesses compile customer or
clientele information and peddle lists to direct marketers usually
without the knowledge or consent of their constituents. Moreover,
list brokers and other companies purchase information and glean data
from various sources to develop detailed profiles and dossiers for
further commercial exploitation.

Unfortunately, this data gets into the hands of con artists who
perpetrate fraud against the unsuspecting consumer. The customer list
of

NEW YORKER magazine, for example, rents for
over $26,000 whereas the
list of the WALL STREET JOURNAL costs $168,000.
As many as 75% of
nonprofit organizations rent or exchange donor lists without the
consent of the contributors. In other examples, it has been reported
that a national weight loss group sold its membership list to a
company that
sells chocolate candy. A nonprofit group fighting Sudden Death
syndrome sold a donor list to a broker who then tried to sell the
list to others marketing the list as a good pool of potential
customers for children's products, even though some lost their
babies. A dating service, which had promised confidentiality to its
clients, sold their names to a company that marketed the list as a
group of singles and as potential buyers of specialized foods. Some
businesses and organizations are concerned about the privacy concerns
of consumers. While Red Cross, Reader's Digest and AT&T refuse to
rent their lists to others, many businesses who trade or offer names
for rent or sale give their customers the option to restrict the sale
of their information (e.g. American Express, Lands End). Since 1980,
the disabled American Veterans has been one of the major non-profits
to include a statement on its solicitations advising donors that it
occasionally rents its mailing list and advising donors to notify
them if they want their names deleted. As a result of database
marketing and computer matching, marketers identify customers for
targeting marketing and other solicitations. Because of waste and
inefficiencies in direct marketing, it would be better
for marketers and others to institute the opt-out process because
the marketing lists would consist of better prospects -- those
consumers who chose not to opt-out. One can argue that bills or other
solicitations providing for an opt-out for consumers enables
marketers and businesses to target hotter prospects, those that
really want to receive the solicitations.

The public is making it increasingly clear that they are worried about
the wide distribution of personal information and what, ultimately,
others may do with this information or construe it to mean. Several
studies and surveys have revealed that consumers are very concerned
about this breach of privacy and want to make their own choices in
the marketplace.

In the American Express Study 1988 -- 90% of those surveyed did not
think that companies disclose enough about their list usage practices
and 80% were of the opinion that companies should not give out
personal information to others. In Cambridge Reports--Trend and
Forecasts Technology and Consumers: Jobs, ed, and privacy 1989
survey, 2 out of 3 consumers indicated that personal privacy is
important with many saying that they feared that their privacy is in
jeopardy. One-half of those surveyed believed new laws are needed for
the protection of privacy. In addition, in a recent Harris Poll,
commissioned by Equifax, 79% of those surveyed were concerned about
threats to their privacy. Only 64% had expressed the same fears in a

1978 poll. Most business executives shared this concern -- 70% of
bank and thrift execs, 67% insurance execs, and 66% of the direct
marketers. Of those questioned, 71% stated that consumers have lost
control over how personal info is circulated and used by companies.
More than 69% were opposed to direct marketers being able to buy from
list making companies information about their consumer
characteristics. Moreover, 76% opposed companies being able to
purchase from credit bureaus names and addresses of consumers
who meet certain criteria.

Furthermore, in a recent Time Magazine Poll on Privacy, 76% of the
people were concerned about the amount of computerized information
that business and government collect and store.  In addition,
90% of the people said companies that collect and sell information
should be prohibited from selling data on household income; 86%
on bill-paying history; 83% medical history; and 68% on product
purchases.  Finally, 93%
of the people agreed that companies that sell data should be required
by law to ask permission from individuals before making the
information available. This bill also addresses the complaint that
there is too much paper invading the homes of consumers. By
estimates, the average American is on more than 50 mailing lists. Six
to 10,000 catalog retailers use mailing lists to send out nearly 11.8
billion catalogs a year.
Over the course of a lifetime, the average American will devote 8
entire months to shifting through mail solicitations. Last year about
41 lbs.
of junk mail have been generated for each adult American consuming
millions of trees each year. Of the pile that reached mailboxes, an
estimated 44% landed in trash cans, unopened and unread, thereby
contributing to our solid waste crisis. Discards amount to more than
2% of the total clutter in our landfills. Another related complaint
is that checks, credit cards, and other valuables get lost in the
mounds of paper that consumers toss out daily. Because the volume of
unsolicited mail is so great, people are paying less attention to
each commercial piece they receive. Even businesses who have a
relationship with the customer often have to convey a message several
times in order to secure the consumer's attention. Thus unsolicited
requests cause the price of other direct mail services to increase.
From a data protection viewpoint, these marketing actions violate the
Code of Fair Information Practices, a set of privacy principles
drafted by government representatives and computer and privacy
experts in 1973 to minimize the privacy risks of automated systems
containing personal information. The core principle that any
information obtained for one purpose should not be used for another
purpose without the consent of the person is central
to the issue. It is based on the premise that when someone gives
personal information for a particular purpose -- to obtain a
warranty, to reserve expects that information will not be used for
another purpose without consent. This bill balances the privacy
interests of consumers with business interests.

While the bill does not outlaw the practice or prohibit companies from
collecting and selling records of customer information and
transactions without written consent, the proposal establishes an
opt-out policy which has been adopted by many responsible businesses.
The proposal is consistent with the federal Telephone Consumer
Protection Act of 1991, which was enacted into law to safeguard the
privacy rights of consumers.
Under that law, an opt-out system is mandated to prevent the marketing
of listings of those who object to receiving unsolicited telephone
calls.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
The act shall take effect on the ninetieth day after it shall have
become a law.
